intro: Fimbrillaria baccharoides, commonly known as the sandverbena, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils, often in arid or semi-arid environments. The plant features small, opposite leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, and it produces clusters of small, white or pale pink flowers. It is part of the Loasaceae family and is characterized by its low-growing, sprawling habit. The species is adapted to withstand drought and high temperatures, making it well-suited to its native habitat.
